description: From Middle English mynute, minute, mynet, from Old French minute, from Medieval Latin minūta (“60th of an hour; note”). Doublet of menu.

entries.meaning: A unit of time equal to sixty seconds (one-sixtieth of an hour).
examples: You have twenty minutes to complete the test.

entries.meaning: (informal) A short but unspecified time period.
examples: Wait a minute, I’m not ready yet!
Synonyms: instant, jiffy, mo, moment, sec, second, tic

entries.meaning: A unit of angle equal to one-sixtieth of a degree.
examples: We need to be sure these maps are accurate to within one minute of arc.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural, minutes) A (usually formal) written record of a meeting or a part of a meeting.
examples: Let’s look at the minutes of last week’s meeting.

entries.meaning: A unit of purchase on a telephone or other similar network, especially a cell phone network, roughly equivalent in gross form to sixty seconds' use of the network.
examples: If you buy this model, you’ll get 100 free minutes.

entries.meaning: A point in time; a moment.
A nautical or a geographic mile.
An old coin, a half farthing.
(obsolete) A very small part of anything, or anything very small; a jot; a whit.
(architecture) A fixed part of a module.
(slang, US, Canada, dialectal) A while or a long unspecified period of time
examples: Oh, I ain't heard that song in a minute!

verbs.description: minute (third-person singular simple present minutes, present participle minuting, simple past and past participle minuted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) Of an event, to write in a memo or the minutes of a meeting.
To set down a short sketch or note of; to jot down; to make a minute or a brief summary of.

description: Borrowed from Latin minūtus (“small", "petty”), perfect passive participle of minuō (“make smaller”).

examples: They found only minute quantities of chemical residue on his clothing.
Synonyms: infinitesimal, insignificant, minuscule, tiny, trace; see also Thesaurus:tiny
Antonyms: big, enormous, colossal, huge, significant, tremendous, vast

entries.meaning: Very careful and exact, giving small details.
examples: The lawyer gave the witness a minute examination.
Synonyms: exact, exacting, excruciating, precise, scrupulous; see also Thesaurus:meticulous
